cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.

div.p:
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
—— Cholera at Meooa.
An_ isolated case of cholera is reported from Mecca.
Now Quay Appointment.
» Mohamed Effendi Khatta, Ministry of Just: ice, has been appointed Superintendent of the Alexandria quays.
The Coldstream Cuarde.
The annual sports of the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards will be held on the Slade ground, Abbassia, on Thursday next.
Bubonie Plague. There aré now 19 cases of plagne under treatment, One case has been discharged cured and one has ended fatally at: Alexandria.

Hasheesh Smuggling. The Coast ‘Guards Administration -seized 106 kilos and 850 grammes of hasheesh in the Port Said’ harbour on the 12th inst. this being the second seizure made at Port Said within the fortnight.

Cairo Water Commission. A Council of Ministers will be heldthis week, and the report of the special water commission will be one of the subjects submitted to the Council. We understanéthat this report is in every way a favourable one.

Savoy Hotel, Cairo. The first small dance of the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will be held next Saturday. Tables for dinner and supper should be booked early as numerous, orders haye already been given. The Old Rugbeian Dinner will also be held at the Savoy on the same evening.

Cairo Scientific Society, Members Of the Cairo Scientific Society are invited to inspect the Rodah Bridge by invita- tion of Mr. A. J: Knowles, on Thursday next. A paper will be read before the Society by Mr. Knowles, at a later date, describing * the construction of the Bridge.

‘ Y. W. 6. A. Cairo. The sale of work of the Young Women’s Christian Association, Cairo, which will be opened at 3.30 p.m. to-morrow by Lady Gorst at the Semiramis Hotel, will be re-opened at the same hour on the following day by Lady Blanche Smith at-Connaught House;

Coal Imports. : Between January 1 and December 1.291,617 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 711,207 tons wete Welsh, 158,579 12 * Noweastle, 186,149 Yorkshire, 100,080 Scotch and 135,602 other qualities. During the corres- ponding period of last year the imports totalled 1,217,384:

Nativé Criminal Court. The Criminal Court of Alexandria which met-on the 14th inst. under the presidency of Judge- Mohamed Bey Said, Councillor to the Court of Appeal,.have sentenced Akeel Saad, Saad Ahmed, and *Abnbaker Massad, who murdered the Omdeh of Zarka village, to im prisonment with hard labour for life.

Bandmann’s Comedy Company. Maurice E. Bandmann has arranged for his London Comedy Company.to appear for two weeks at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, in the latter part of April and beginning of May next. The company has carried every- thing before it during their eighteen months -tour in India and the Far East. While in Cairo they will give the following popular London successes :— “Raffles,” “His House in Order,” ‘The Walls of Jericho,’ “The Christ- ian.” ‘The Morals of Marcus,” “John Glade's Honour,” “Che Admirable Crichton,” ‘Peter's Mother,” “Old Heidelberg,” “Sherlock Holm- es,” “The Earl of Pawtucket,” and “Sunday.” The repertoire is certainly an excellent one and seding that the company 1s carrying some fifty tons of scenery we are likely to see each piece staged in the same elaborate mauner as in London.
ALEXANDRIA CONSERVATOIRE OF MUSIC.

The fifth annual entertainment given by the } pupils of the above flourishing institution took place on Saturday in the Lifontr concert hall, and’ attracted*a large and’ fashionable “audience. Most ofthe items showed a dec idedl improvement on last year's. pe ‘rformance, which was more particnlarly marked in the individual numbers. The choruses might be much more forcibly. rendered. appeared to be an absence of any attempt at accentuate the light and shade which 1s 80 necessary in order to produce the’ effects in- tended in such achorosas Verdi's “I Profughi Scozzesi” trom Macbeth.

The same remark applies to the chorus “‘La Primavera” in*the sécond part. The soprano solo in this, Azzarelli, whose perfofmance was rather spoil- ed, however, by an evident nervousness. In Mayerbeer’s romance “Sic Vendicata’ Prof, Gianni Galletti put forward one -of his best pupils in Sig. D.Lambridis,who has a fine yoice. of excellent.quality and his tasteful rendering was much appreciated. Schumann’s duet “for soprano and tenor “La Danza” was pleasingly he instrumental numbers. were particularly good. Sig. Perdichidis and ig. R.. Scinica gave violin, solos in @ manner which was most comméndable. Messtfs. Te: and J. Papasian are worthy of more than passing notice: each worked hard and contributed considerably to thé suecess of the enter- tainment. We congratulate. Signore. Gianni Galletti. Lama, Colella, Romeo, and Onesti, on the excellent progress made by the pupils.

COMPANIES IN EGYPT: SUPREME COURT'S DECISIONS. Judge:Cator in the Supreme British Con- sular Court~delivered judgment this morning on the two appeals of the Bourse and Banking Company Ltd against the judgments of the Consular Court given on the 20th November last. The Appeal Court dismissed both appeals and ordered the Bourse and Banking Company to pay the costs in the Court below and on the appeals.

These decision of the Supreme Court to up- hold the judgments of the lower Court, given on the 20th ulto., are of great importance as all thie numérous limited liabilities companies, registered under the companies Acts, «whose sphere of operations are in Egypt, are now declared to be amenable to the jurisdiction of the British Consular Courts, whether their boards are composed of subjects of foreign Powers or not. In the one case an application was made by an English shareholder of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited, represented by Mr. Gooding for the removal of the liquidator, appointed at the meeting of the shareholders and the appointment of a liquidatornominated by the Court. Mr. Devon- shire, who represented the company contended that the court had (4) no jurisdiction onder section 12 of the Order in Council, (2) no jurisdiction in that the circumstances do not admit of same under section 107 of the Order unless, under section 167, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs should make an order covering a case where the circumstances do not permit.

The Court held that the question at issue fell Within jurisdiction as the plaintiff isa British subject and the defendant compuny of the same nationality,whereby the Mixed Courts could have no jurisdiction. Council for the defence appealed to the Supreme Court, which has now decided that the Court had jurisdiction.

In the second case, the plaintiff, an English shareholder in the same company, represented by Mr. Reginald Silley, brought an action on the tollowing grounds. The plaintiff had been allotted 200 shares in the Company which he sold at a premium of #5. Subsequently, on the announcement that the bearer warrants were ready, plaintiff applied through the Anglo- Egyptian Bank for delivery of same. He was requested by the company to sign a form in accordance with the regulations of the Alexandria Bourse, or otherwise the company would not make the delivery. The plaintiff filled up the form, expunging the words “according to the Alexandria Bourse require- ments.” Mr. Silley sabmitted that such con- dition in the form was unfair and interfered with ‘the rights of private contract and, therefore, the company is improperly retaining the warrants. Mr. Devonshire, for the company contended that art. 47 of the company’s sta- tutes fully empowered the directors to de- termine the conditions upon which* the bearer warrants should be issued and to settle the form of application for the same. The. lower Court held that the directors were not justified in attaching such condition and gaye judg- ment for the plaintiff for the delivery of the warrants or £200 and costs. The Bourse and Banking Company, appealed against this decision, but, as already announ- ced, the Supreme Court dismissed the appeai.
The full bearings of these decisions will be considered in another issue.
THE KHEDIVE

Sir-Eldon Gorst was received in audience by the Khedive on Saturday morning and his Highness also granted audicaces to Lemaire Bey. Crookshank Pasha, Mr. Pacliano, Rouma- nian Consul General, Mr. Smyrnoff, Russian Diplomatic Agent, ‘who introduced Prince Mi- chael Gortchacoff, Chevalier Serra, Italian acting Diplomatic Agent, who introduced Mr, Pan] Brenna, Count Bernsdorff, German Diplo- matic Agent, Dr. von Campe and Mattre Carton de Wiart.
PILGRIMS AT BEYROU®P.
‘DISTINGUISHED PASSENGERS. (FROM uUR OWN CORRESPONDENT. )

Beyrout, December 12. The Khedivial Mailliner S.8. “Tantah’ arrived yesterday from Constantinople with a contin- gent of pilgrims for Mecca among whom were the following distinguished personages: the mother of the present Shah of Persia, Sultan Mobam- med Ali, and his brother Prince Nasreddine Mirza, with a large retinue of Ulemas etc. The Prince is only eleven~ years of age and is said to be endowed with remarkable intelligence. After the official visits to the Seraglio and the Per- sian Consulate General, his Highness stopped: with his mother as honoured guests at the Vali’s residence for the night and then proceeded by the some boat next day toCaiffa,where they are to take the Hedjaz Railway for the sacred towns. The S;. “Tantah” took from Beyrout 315 pilgrims.
EGYPTIAN’ POLITICS.
THE REPUBLICAN PARTY.

The formation of an. Egyptian, Repebliean Nationalist party is still exciting a good deal of discussion, for the demand for thé’ immedia te constitution of an’ antonomous’ automatic, and independent republic of Egypt has at- tracted a good deal of notice. A vernacular contemporary remarks :—

It appears now that. the leader of this. new movement is an editor. who acted as assistant and counsellor to thesupposed leader. of the Egyptian Liberals. Well, liberalism bas in many ¢éases led to republicanism and even to socialism, and we are .in the same boat with other nations. But who is the candidate for the presidency according to present arran- gements?
THE COPTIC. PARTY

“Al Watan,” the Coptic Cairo organ, in’a notice of the Coptic party, says :— ~ The coptic party was given® the death blow by the refusal of “Al-Watan” to” work=for ite constructions; Yet some:individuals talk ofits coming formation and say that it will not insiat upon the public useof the ancient Coptic language as the basis-of its political mission.

THE NATIONALIST EXTREMISTS.
The general assembly of the active-members of the National Party will take place atthe “Lewa” office on Friday the 27th. inst) in order to select. the committee of direction: and to approve the statutes. “Our Direetor,” says the “Egyptian Standard,” “will deliver-an im« portant political discourse. on the-occasion.”
PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
A Cairo correspondent writes :—
Great indignation has been aroused among. the various political parties in Cairo atthe, news that Abdul Razik Pasha has had a mani-, festo published in the London “Standard,” outlining the aims of the Party of the People. The other parties of “‘Nationalistic” proclivities, recognise that the handful of political busy- bodies in England, who take an interest.in, Egypt, will soon be so confased as to the state of affairs here that they will be quite unable to know which ‘Party’ topatronise. The Moderate Nationalists and the Egyptian Liberals have:} each had various maniféstoes published in the, London newspapers and now that the Party of the People has secured a footing in the English; Press, it will be difficult for the Radi¢als to. distinguish one party from the other, especially as they are all, collectively and individually, anathematised by Mustapha Pasha Kamel. The leader of the Nationalist Extremists is very, much chagrined at Abdul Razik Pasha’s in auguration of a forward policy in the London Press, for not only hus he lost the’ patronage of Mr. Robertson, M:P.~ and’ Aborigines Pro- tection Society, but he has seen his influence in England undermined by the Moderates and the recent’ foundation of the party of the Constitutional Reformers-has: still further in- creased his vexation. NoW.even the Party of the People, which he always affected to despise, has gained a hearing. in Exgland and of eourse every tresh party helps to diminish his in- fluence as the sole and supreme head of the National Movement.
MIXED COURTS. a
